Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story: It’s Saturday afternoon, and I’m at my desk, headset on, trying to keep my voice steady as a customer on the line grows more agitated. She’s been with our company for years, and now she’s questioning every detail of the offer I’m supposed to sell. My manager expects me to handle objections smoothly, to keep the call going, to not let a customer slip away. I’m searching for the right words, my mind racing, when my phone buzzes with a message from Mom: “Just checking in, hope you’re okay. Love you.” I haven’t replied to her last text from two days ago. Guilt tugs at me—she just wants to know I’m alright, to hear from her son, even if it’s just a quick hello. But the customer’s voice sharpens, demanding answers, and I know my supervisor is listening in. I feel split in two, the pressure mounting from both sides. I want to reassure my mom, but I can’t lose focus on the call. My thumb hovers over my phone, my mind torn between the demands of being a good son and a reliable employee.
